summary: tropism of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) (27), poliovirus (32), and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus (15) are strongly influenced by the capacity of the virus to bind specific receptors. infection of discrete regions within the central nervous system (CNS) by strains of adeno-associated virus (AAV) is dependent on carbohydrate-binding specificity. type 3 reovirus strains spread to the CNS using neural and hematogenous routes. these serotype-specific differences in tropism and disease segregate genetically with the viral S1 gene (43, 44), which encodes attachment protein 1 (26, 45) and nonstructural protein 1s (9, 17, 35) both S1 gene products influence reovirus pathogenesis (1, 5–7, 23), with the 1 protein thought to target the virus to discrete cell types in the s between 1 and SA involve residues at the N-terminal portion of the body domain, between -spiral repeats 2 and 3. reovirus serotypes engage JAM-A (8, 30), they differ in carbohydrate coreceptor utilization, suggesting that carbohydrate binding by 1 influences reovirus pathology in the CNS. Arg202 side chain forms a bidentate salt bridge with the carboxylate moiety of SA. the replacement of Arg202 with a tryptophan in T3D-1R202W would remove the electrostatic interaction between the arginine and SA. it is therefore unlikely that the mutant can bind to SA. Arg202 (cyan) of wild-type T3D forms a salt bridge with the carboxylate group of SA (31) this bond is represented by a dashed red line, illustrating that it is likely lost when Arg202 is replaced with a tryptophan (modeled in yellow) the wild-type strain produced lower titers in the livers of infected mice. reovirus is delivered initially to the CNS by hematogenous routes (1, 6) it is possible that bloodstream dissemination of the mutant virus is subtly enhanced in comparison to the wild-type virus. if so, this difference was not sufficient to permit detection in our assays. type 3 interactions are key determinants of reovirus virulence in the CNS.
